articles.description: The White House is ebullient about reaching a potential new NAFTA deal as soon as this week — with only Mexico. But that strategy could run into roadblocks thanks to the law that allowed the Trump administration to fast-track talks on the 25-year-old deal in …

articles.author: Daryl Guppy
articles.title: Oil's uptrend remains intact
articles.description: Oil's price hasn't rebounded, but many features of the commodity's performance suggest the bear is not in command of this market, Daryl Guppy writes.

articles.title: Stocks are seen extending gains at the open on Wall Street
articles.description: The Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq get a chance to rise for a fourth straight day and a fifth time in six sessions.

articles.title: Trump's tariffs are starting to hit US consumers where it hurts
articles.description: President Donald Trump's tariffs are starting to hit average American consumers. The latest example: a cost increase for aluminum dog tags in Dane County, Wisconsin. The county had to pay $2,200 for dog tags this year, up 46% from last year. Small businesses …

articles.author: Reuters Editorial
articles.title: China urges local governments to shut excess steel capacity, ban illegal subsidies
articles.description: China on Tuesday urged local authorities to strictly comply with Beijing-issued policies shutting excessive steel capacity and banning export and import subsidies for steel companies that violate World Trade Organization rules.

articles.description: The legal filing comes after the tech giant admitted that it stores users' location history even if they switch it off.

articles.title: Europe Must Create New Monetary Fund That Leaves U.S. Out to Save Iran Deal, Germany Says
articles.description: German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas said Europe must create a new system for financial transactions that excludes the U.S. in order to help Iran.

articles.title: Ghouta Chemical Attack: Syria's Assad Remains Unrestrained, Unpunished and Unrepentant Five Years On
articles.description: There have been hundreds of chemical attacks in Syria since 2011, but Bashar al-Assad continues to be protected by his Russian allies.
